options: The amount of memory to be allocated should be known beforehand.
Elements of an array can be accessed in constant time.

questions.answer: The amount of memory to be allocated should be known beforehand.

questions.question: Which of the following is a Divide and Conquer algorithm?
questions.explanation: Merge Sort is a Divide and Conquer algorithm.

questions.question: What will be the best sorting algorithm, given that the array elements are small (<= 1e6)?
questions.explanation: Counting sort sorts an array in O(n) time complexity, taking up an extra space complexity of O(max(a[i])).

questions.question: Which of the following are applications of Topological Sort of a graph?
questions.explanation: All the above options are applicable.

questions.question: Which of the following is known to be not an NP-Hard Problem?
questions.explanation: The 0/1 Knapsack is not an NP-Hard problem.

questions.question: Consider the following code snippet: void solve(vector<int> &a) { int queries; cin >> queries; while(queries--) { int type; cin >> type; if(type == 1) { int index, value; cin >> index >> value; update(a, index, value); } else { int l, r; cin >> l >> r; cout << getXOR(a, l, r) << endl; } } } The update() function updates the element at the given index in the array to some given value. The getXOR() function returns the XOR of the elements in the array a, in the range [l, r]. Which of the following data structures can perform the above tasks optimally?
questions.explanation: Segment trees would be an optimal choice for such operations.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about AVL Trees?
options: The difference between the heights of left and right nodes cannot be more than 1.
The height of an AVL Tree always remains of the order of O(logn)
AVL Trees are a type of self-balancing Binary Search Trees.
questions.explanation: All the above options are applicable for an AVL Tree.

options: Calculates the number of edges in an undirected graph.
Calculates the number of nodes in a given graph.
Calculates the sum of degrees of all nodes in a given graph.
questions.answer: Calculates the number of edges in an undirected graph.
questions.explanation: The above code snippet calculates the number of edges in an undirected graph.

questions.question: In a graph of n nodes and n edges, how many cycles will be present?
questions.explanation: A tree contains by definition n nodes and n - 1 edges, and it is an acyclic graph. When we add 1 edge to the tree, we can form exactly one cycle by adding this edge.

questions.question: A node in a tree, such that removing it splits the tree into forests, with size of each connected component being not greater than n / 2 is called?
questions.explanation: Such a node in a tree is called a centroid of the tree.
